Residence + Address in Africa P. Strickland Goree Senegal West Africa
div1.p:
No.16...US Consular, Goree-Dakar October 22nd, 1884
Mr. Peter Strickland To the Department of State
Subject Response to Circular dated August 21st 1884, asking for information with a view to the of the Consular Service
div1.ab:
No. 16 U.S Consulate, Goree Dakar October 22nd 1884
To the Honorable John Davis Assistant Secretary of State Washington
div1.p: Sir: By last mail I received a Circular dated August 21st, 1884 requesting information with a view to the reargausation of the Consular service, I will then as briefly as may be, and of necessity in round roughly estimated numbers, give you as graphic an idea as I can of French Senegal, its commercial facilities and its possibilities.
Geographically, French Senegal extends from the "Great Desert" to near Sierra Leone, embracing a section of Coast about six hundred miles in length, for the most

part extremely fertile, and abounding with navigable Rivers which render access to the interior comparatively cheap and easy. Of these the Sebegal River is navigable for 600 miles during half of the year, and is being connected with the Niger bby a Railrad from Bafavlake to Bammakou which will give it the trade of the whole upper Niger valley. The other Rivers of importance are the Salvum, the Casamausa the Casaini, the Nuners, the Ponga, the Debreeka, and the Mellancee; all navigable for distances ranging from 10 to 150 miles.--

Sandwhiched between the French sections of Coast are some English Settlements confined closely to the banks of the Gambia, which is a magnificent River vavigable for 400 miles, and some Portuguese settlements about

Bulama, where there are also three fine Rivers each navigable far more than a hundred miles. The Commerce of both the English and Portuguese possessions is essentially under French control, and Goree, Dakar from its central position and accessibility to mail steamers is the Commercial emporium of the whole coast.

Of cities+ towns, St. Louis, built in handsome European style on an island in the Senegal River, is the capitol, with a large commerce, and contains with its about 30,000 inhabitants. Goree-Dakar with their envisions, including Rufisk in sight on the Game Boy, contain fully 25,000 inhabitants, and there are numerous turns further South in French Senegal which contain from one to five thousand inhabitants, all

doing a thriving trade with Goree, (which is a free port) by means of Coaster ranging from 10 to 150 tons, many of them tindered with Mahogany and rarewood which abounds at different palces on the Coast.

The magnificent Bay of Goree is 20 miles across from East to West deep, forming one of the Gafest and most Capacious harbors in the world. It contains no detached changers of consequencce, the navigation being clean in all parts at the distance of a mile from the Shore; and in it no lasting gale even blows. Of its present commerce + have no statistics at hand from which to infer the amount, but have seen,
of which there are about always a number in port, more than ten thousands tons of shipping in the Bay at one time.

A Railroad, was begun from taken last year, and trains are now ruming over it into the interior upwards of 30 miles, and it is designed next year to have it extended as far as St. Louis, more than a hundred miles. The telegraph already connects the two pleaces, which is to cummest by Cable next year to the Canaries, and from thence to Europe.
The Mails, to Europe are carried by the Steamers of the + Moritive Company, which are from three to four thousands tons each, and

in going and coming call at Goree four times a month. In addition to there we have a baot from the English line of steamers once a mouth, and one from a Ramburgh line of steamers once a month, besides several belonging to merchants vehicle sometimes carry the mails best do not make their trips regularly.

Amount of American Trade The Amount of American Gouds at prevent consumed yearly in French Senegal Cannal amount to less than one Million dollars in value , but of this only about one fifth part is brought here by Americans, who have been steadily driven off by competition because the conditions of the trade are against them. French agents in Boston and New York such

Goods only as can be obtained an reasonable terms in America, and either chip them direct mostly in foreign vessels which afterwards load groundnuts for Europe or else they ship them to Europe by steam from whence they are brought clown here in vessels which carry on the Trade reguarly.

Owing to this state of affairs, which in my opinion might easily be prevented, our direct commerce is not holding its own in this one of the fairest prospecture markets in the world; there being not less than 3,000,000 of natives here noe fairly under French jurisdiction, with wants which American Caew supply better than others increasing in almost a rates, and good produce to exchange for goods.

But I hope to explain fully about this in the near future, and will now end by stating that with the present depressing influences there will not probably be expointed dusty to America from Goree Dakar in more than $60,000 in Produce. It will consist of hides, plum. Capol and Fudia Rubber, and much of the same kinds of produce vanish go from here to Europe will finally reach America to pay for goods which French agents buy and ships from there.
We foregoing remains I hope will serve to give the Government a sufficient Counsular service, but there is much that would perhaps be more interesting to be

added as soon as some statistics will be available at the conculsion of the current quarter. In brief it seems to me that Goree- Dakar is one of the most important places between Cape Spartel and that of Good Hope. Only that it has a somewhat unsavory reputation on rcent of epedemics Dakar would soon rival St. Dicante as a coaling station for steamers, and as things are it does a good deal of that business. There is unfortunately us question but what the Coast of Africa is unhealthy for Europeans, but Goree Dakar is one of the best places an it in that respect-- probably the very best place.
Of Governors, Senegal has far a long time had Faidresube one of the must distingushed

of her Generals and more recently Briere d'l l'Fole, at present high in command in Tangrin. Law the Colony would relish the American representation here changed back to a vice consulate as seen to be proposed I can only give form a long knowledge of the French Charater, but I presume I shll not do wrong in that I think such a measure would be hardly favorable to American interests here, and perhaps course whoever held the position to be treated with a frigid by far from agreable. I am sir with respect Very truly Yours Peter Strickland US Consul
